title: Property List Views
narrative:
A property list is more than just a wrapper around values.
    This interfaces has a rich API that exposes a plethora of methods,
    many of which are designed to inform you about
    their contents without actually exposing them to you.

    For these facts about any property list, we can create views.
    These views are observables live properties that are updated

features.id: The `viewSize()` method returns a property that is equal to the size of the original property.

extraInfo:
Calling `viewSize()` on a property list
            will be a view on the `size()` method of said property list.
            So when the integer returned by `size()` changes,
            the value of the view will change too.

blocks.text: A non empty property list containing a few japanese words.
code: Vars<String> words = Vars.of("ブランコツリー","は","いい","です")

blocks.text: A view on the size of the property list.
The view is 4 initially.
We add a word to the property list.
The view becomes 5.

The sentence becomes "ブランコツリーはいいですね",
                which means "SwingTree is nice, isn't it?"
code: words.toList() == ["ブランコツリー","は","いい","です","ね"]

blocks.text: We remove a word from the property list.
The view becomes 4 again.

features.id: We can "view the emptiness" of a property list.

extraInfo:
The method `viewIsEmpty()` on a property list
            will return a property that is true when the list is empty,
            and false otherwise.

            Whenever the boolean returned by `isEmpty()` changes,
            the value of the view will change too.

            So this is effectively a live view on the `isEmpty()` method of the property list.

blocks.text: A list of 2 words say ing "cute cat" in japanese.
A view on the emptiness of the property list.
The view is false initially.
We remove all the words from the property list.
The view becomes true.

features.id: We can "view the presence of items" of a property list.

extraInfo:
The method `viewIsNotEmpty()` on a property list
            will return a property that is true when the list is not empty,
            and false otherwise.

            Whenever the boolean returned by `isNotEmpty()` changes,
            the value of the view will change too.

            So this is effectively a live view on the `isNotEmpty()` method of the property list.

blocks.text: An empty list of words.
A view on the presence of the items in the property list.
The view is false initially.
We add the japanese word for "cute" to the property list.
The view becomes true.

features.id: The `view(U,U,Function<T,U>)` method creates a dynamically updated life view of its source list.

extraInfo:
Similar to `Val.view(U,U,Function<T,U>)`, the `Vals.view(U,U,Function<T,U>)` method
            creates a sort of read only clone of the original property list, which gets
            updated automatically whenever the original list changes.

blocks.text: A property list of 3 days of the week.
A view on the names of the days of the week.
The view contains ["MONDAY","WEDNESDAY","FRIDAY"] initially.
We add a day to the source property list.
The view becomes ["MONDAY","WEDNESDAY","FRIDAY","SATURDAY"].
We now remove a day from the property list.
The view becomes ["WEDNESDAY","FRIDAY","SATURDAY"].
The source list is cleared.
The view becomes empty.

features.id: A property list view created using `view(U,U,Function<T,U>)` will receive change events from its source.

extraInfo:
A property list view created using `view(U,U,Function<T,U>)`
            will receive change events from its source.

blocks.text: A property list of 3 months of the year.
A view on the names of the months of the year.
A listener that records the changes and notes the new values.
Initially, the traces are empty.
We add a month to the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We remove a month from the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We clear the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We add a two months to the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We call `addAllAt(2, Month.SEPTEMBER, Month.OCTOBER)` on the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We remove the range of months from the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
Finally, we check if the view and source property have the expected contents:
We set a range to a particular month.
The view receives the change event.
Finally we check again if the view and source property have the expected contents:
We make the source list distinct.
The view is updated.
The traces recorded the change.

features.id: A property list view created using `view()` will receive change events from its source.

extraInfo:
A property list view created using `view()` is a no-op view
            which will receive change events from its source, so that 
            it is always in sync with the source and can be used as a
            way to receive change events from the source.

blocks.text: A property list of 3 months of the year and its view.
A listener that records the changes and notes the new values.
Initially, the traces are empty.
We add a month to the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We remove a month from the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We clear the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We add a two months to the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We call `addAllAt(2, Month.SEPTEMBER, Month.OCTOBER)` on the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We remove the range of months from the source property list.
The view receives the change event.
We check if the view and source property have the expected contents:
We set a range to a particular month.
The view receives the change event.
Finally we check again if the view and source property have the expected contents:
We make the source list distinct.
The view is updated.
The traces recorded the change.

features.id: The properties of a list view can themselves be observed for changes in the source properties

extraInfo:
The properties of a list view can be accessed using 
            the `Val<T> at(int)` method.
            This returns a new property that will be updated
            whenever the value at the given index in the source list changes.

blocks.text: A property list of 3 days of the week and two types of views.
Two trace lists to record the changes.
Listeners to record the changes.
We change the first day in the list.
The view of the first day receives the change event.
We change the second day in the list.
The view of the second day receives the change event.
We change the third day in the list.
The view of the third day receives the change event.

features.id: Calling `revert()` on a property list will also revert its views.

extraInfo:
The view of a property list (a `Viewables<T>`) is a live view
            on the source property list. This means that whenever the source
            property list changes, the view will change too.
            This is also true for the `revert()` operation.
            So calling `revert()` on a property list will also revert its views.

blocks.text: A property list of 4 educational documentaries.
code: Vars<String> documentaries = Vars.of("Dominion", "Land of Hope and Glory", "Earthlings", "Cowspiracy")

blocks.text: A double view on the property list, representing the average word length of each documentary.
Finally, we also create a list for tracking the change events.
The view has the correct initial state:
We revert the source property list.
The view is also reverted.
